ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to think about the law and gained a broad understanding of the First Amendment. Professor Goodrow really makes sure everyone understands how legal precedence works and is applied to new cases.
Gained the ability to read and critically analyze court decisions. Also developed a better ability to communicate my thoughts and ideas regarding complex topics.
I learned about the freedom of speech under the First Amendment, its challenges and limitations, and various ethical and constitutional approaches to these issues.
Flexibility of thought, openness of discourse, and unique approaches to interpreting the law.
I learned about issues tied to free speech & expression from both legal and ethical standpoints.
I learned much more about free speech and the different cases surrounding the First Amendment!
Learned all about the first amendment and its implications on American society and free speech.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is an incredible course and Professor Goodrow is a fantastic professor. The syllabus is amazing -- a great blend of court cases and supplementary reading + documentaries. The people who decide to take this course often come in with specific areas of interest that relate to the First Amendment, and I learned a lot from them as well. Finally, the classroom environment is awesome. Professor Goodrow had a no laptops policy, and that made the discussions super engaging and meant that everyone prepared their notes in advance. She always responds to questions with great insight and commentary, and is able to steer the discussion in a way that feels incredibly fulfilling.

A very nonchalant classroom environment where class seems more like a conversation than a course. Great material and professor that makes the course fun and steers class in the right directions when the class gets sidetracked.

I really enjoyed the class, but I do think there could be some more attention spent on the text of the amendment itself, and when its various protections intersect (I.e. freedom of assembly vs speech)

The discussions in this course are fascinating, and the instructor is a judge, so she (obviously) knows the law super well and does a great job of explaining it whenever it's confusing (which is often). I also really appreciated how well kg both directed discussion and encouraged us to engage with other students' points -- she really struck a good balance in a way that seminar instructors don't always do. The only weakness of the class is that discussion got a little off-track some weeks, and we sometimes didn't get to a decent chunk of the syllabus readings. It might've been nice for the pacing to be a little different in that regard (unless there were just fewer syllabus assignments/more recommended rather than required reading). But overall, a great course!
KG is one of the best professors that I have had at Yale! Incredibly supportive and makes the class very engaging
All strengths, no weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely!! If you are at all interested in the law and/or questions of free speech, definitely take this class. It rocks. You will learn so much about how the law works, what the constitution covers and does not cover, how free speech exists in America, and more. I loved it!
Yes it is a great course to explore the first amendment and discuss how the law impacts people in a tangible fashion.
Yes I would. KG is an amazing professor!
Yes I would. KG is the best and the readings and case selections were great. If you dont take her criminal case, take this one!

Yes, if you're interested in learning about free speech through a variety of lenses. This class teaches can teach you a lot about First Amendment-related law if you come in with little knowledge (like I did), but it also reaches beyond that, and class discussions also touch upon ethical issues that affect individuals, private entities (like colleges & social media companies), and society as a whole. I thought a 6:30pm course might be burdensome to attend, but it actually ended up being a really fun two hours of discussion that I truly looked forward to every Wednesday evening.
Yes! One of the best classes I have taken at Yale
Absolutely! KG is amazing.
